cbccore.motors
Class Motor

java.lang.Object
  cbccore.motors.statemotors.AbstractAdvancedStateMotor
      cbccore.motors.statemotors.AbstractBlockingAdvancedStateMotor
          cbccore.motors.Motor
All Implemented Interfaces:
IAdvancedStateMotor, IBlockingAdvancedStateMotor, IStateMotor
Direct Known Subclasses:
Wheel, Wheel
public class Motor
extends AbstractBlockingAdvancedStateMotor

Adds a clean API to replace cbccore.low.Motor, and even adds a few minor features & workarounds for known motor controlling issues.

Author:
Braden McDorman, Benjamin Woodruff
See Also:
Wheel

Constructor Detail

Motor

public Motor(int port)
      throws InvalidPortException
Constructs a Motor which is used to power the robot. Motors are high range (meaning they can rotate an arbitrary amount) low torque (meaning they don't have as much movement power)

Parameters:
port - The port number that the motor is plugged in to
Throws:
InvalidPortException
Method Detail

motor

public void motor(int percent)
Set motor speed. It's recommended you use a Back-EMF based function instead. A Back-EMF function is one that reads the voltage return from the motor so you can better determine the speed and increase the power if neccesary.

Parameters:
percent - percent % of full (-100 to 100)
See Also:
forward(), backward(), moveAtVelocity(int)

clearPositionCounter

public int clearPositionCounter()
Clears the position counter of the motor. The position is counted in ticks.

moveAtVelocity

public int moveAtVelocity(int velocity)
Moves at a velocity in ticks per second

Parameters:
velocity - The velocity to move in ticks per second (-1000 to 1000)

waitForDone

public void waitForDone()
A safer "blockMotorDone()", does not present the possiblity of a program locking up because a motor might get stuck. The only downside is that a motor might not have finished it's movements by the time the function has returned. Might return before the motor has actually stopped moving. If you want to ensure if has stopped, you can call off() or freeze().

See Also:
blockMotorDone(), moveToPosition(int, int), moveRelativePosition(int, int), off(), freeze()

setPidGains

                        int i,
                        int d,
                        int pd,
                        int id,
                        int dd)

freeze

public int freeze()
Actively attempts to keep the motor at the current position (Warning: continues to draw current) Imagine the motors are your legs, freeze() is you attempting to stand in place and resist someone pushing you.

See Also:
off()

getDone

public boolean getDone()
Checks if the motor is moving toward a goal.

Returns:
moving True: The motor is moving toward a goal, False: It isn't

getPositionCounter

public int getPositionCounter()
Checks the motor position

Returns:
position The motor position in ticks (to +/-2147483647)

public int getPosition()
Checks the motor position

Returns:
position The motor position in ticks (to +/-2147483647)

blockMotorDone

public void blockMotorDone()
Stops until the motor is done moving to it's goal.

setPwm

public int setPwm(int pwm)
motor() only from (+/-255).

Parameters:
pwm - The the motor power (+/-255)
See Also:
motor(int), getPwm()

getPwm

public int getPwm()
Checks the current motor power.

Returns:
pwm Returns the current pwm setting (+/-255)
See Also:
setPwm(int)

forward

public void forward()
Moves the motor forward at full power. Not a Back-EMF function.

A Back-EMF fuction such as moveAtVelocity(tps) is recommended.

See Also:
moveAtVelocity(int), backward()

backward

public void backward()
Moves the motor backward at full power. Not a Back-EMF function.

A Back-EMF fuction such as moveAtVelocity(tps) is recommended.

See Also:
moveAtVelocity(int), forward()

off

public void off()
Cut power to this motor

public static void allOff()
Turn off all motors

The default speed is half of maximum (500 ticks per second)
